text: "Little Arrows" is a single by English artist Leapy Lee. Released in 1968, it was the first single from his album Little Arrows. The song peaked at number 2 in his homeland, number 11 on the Billboard Hot Country Singles chart. It also reached number 1 on the RPM Country Tracks chart in Canada. ==Chart performance== {|class="wikitable sortable" !align="left"|Chart (1968) !align="center"|Peak position |- |align="left"|Canadian RPM Country Tracks |align="center"|1 |- |align="left"|Canadian RPM Top Singles |align="center"|8 |- |align="left"|Rhodesia (Lyons Maid Hits Of The Week) |align="center"|1 |- |South Africa (Springbok) |align="center"|2 |- |align="left"|U.K. Singles Chart |align="center"|2 |- |align="left"|U.S. Billboard Hot Country Singles |align="center"|11 |- |align="left"|U.S. Billboard Hot 100 |align="center"|16 |- |U.S. Billboard Adult Contemporary |align="center"|38 |} ==Covers== Little arrows was covered in Spain by the female singer Karina. It has become a well- known melody over the years. It was called "Las Flechas del Amor" and arranged by Waldo de los Ríos. The version hit the number one of the Spanish lists for 6 weeks on March 29, 1969. In Sweden, the version "Amors pilar" was recorded by Ewa Roos and topped the Swedish singles chart "Svensktoppen" for 2 weeks in February, 1969. The Swedish lyrics were written by Stikkan Anderson, later manager of ABBA. ==References== Category:1968 singles Category:Leapy Lee songs Category:RPM Country Tracks number-one singles Category:Songs written by Albert Hammond Category:Songs written by Mike Hazlewood Category:1968 songs Category:Decca Records singles
title: Little Arrows
